repnme.cdata!:
Kyrgyz Republic - Health Sector Reform;
            Second Health Sector Reform Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Rating for the Health Sector Reform
            Project for Kyrgyz Republic are as follows: outcome was
            moderately unsatisfactory; risk to the development outcome
            was moderate; and the performance of the Bank and the
            Borrower was highly satisfactory. Ratings for the Second
            Health Sector Reform Project are as follows: outcome was
            satisfactory; risk to the development outcome was negligible
            low; and the performance of the Bank and the Borrower was
            satisfactory. Lessons learned from the projects included: 1)
            the political economy of health sector reform inevitably
            creates both winners and losers. Early and comprehensive
            anticipation of stakeholder interests, institutional
            analysis to facilitate understanding of those interests, and
            the generation of a coherent plan to build support for
            reform and to persuade and/or co-opt potential opponents is
            essential; 2) the Bank should not, however, underestimate
            the potential leverage wielded by its financing and
            expertise; 3) one effective mechanism for countering
            political resistance to reform is strong and consistent
            Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E), where analytic results
            can be generated and disseminated rapidly and effectively,
            building support for project activities in a politically
            contentious environment; 4) another important tool for
            overcoming political resistance to reform is the engagement
            with civil society organizations that give health
            professionals and users of the health care system a voice in
            the decision process and a clear sense of affiliation and
            identity; and 5) tradeoffs between efficiency,
            equity/access, and quality of care will not be addressed in
            the absence of explicit and consistent attention to the
            balance between them and interventions to correct imbalances.

repnme.cdata!:
Kyrgyz Republic - Second Health Sector
            Reform Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Health Sector
            Reform Project in Kyrgyz Republic were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            moderate, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            borrower performance was satisfactory. Lessons learned
            included: 1) Sound quality at entry is critical; design must
            be supported by solid analytical work; piloting smaller
            scale operations and reforms can help build capacity and
            stakeholder support; 2) Strong Government ownership is not
            sufficient, it must be backed up with resources and budget
            execution must be synchronized with health reforms; 3)
            Explicit assessment of political risks could provide
            guidance to teams embarking on projects that support
            reforms; 4) A lesson on how to undertake health sector
            reforms is that sometimes complex designs are necessary and
            a broader approach could be the only way to achieve the
            expected outcomes. This means that within the Bank, teams
            from different sectors need better coordination that would
            allow for full use of instruments and within a country
            better alignment of frameworks is a must; 5) In a developing
            sector supported by a large number of donors; successful
            donor coordination is critical for successful comprehensive
            reforms and; 6) When health reforms change the role of the
            Ministry of Health (MOH) to one of stewardship, focus must
            also be on institutional development and governance. As a
            steward of health care, more transparency and accountability
            become expected. This means that MOH and the sector as a
            whole need stronger and transparent fiduciary function
            (procurement, financial management).
